payload.instructions:
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
Source code lives in `src`. Routes and layouts use the App Router under `src/app`, with segment folders like `src/app/[lineId]` for dynamic pages and `src/app/api` for server handlers. Reusable UI sits in `src/components`, while feature-specific logic is grouped inside `src/features/<feature>`. Shared hooks (`src/hooks`), database helpers (`src/lib`), and design tokens (`src/styles`) keep cross-cutting concerns centralized. Static assets (logos, favicons) belong in `public`. Keep new modules aligned with this layout so imports remain predictable.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `npm run dev`: Launches the Next.js dev server with React Fast Refresh.
- `npm run build`: Produces an optimized production bundle; run before deploys.
- `npm run start`: Serves the latest build locally for smoke-testing production output.
- `npm run lint`: Executes the project-wide ESLint rules (Next.js core-web-vitals baseline). Treat warnings as errors before opening a PR.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
Use modern ES modules with functional React components. Prefer two-space indentation and trailing commas, matching the existing files. Components that render UI should use PascalCase filenames (`ThemeToggle.jsx`), hooks use camelCase prefixed with `use` (`use-mobile.js`), and utility modules go in `src/lib` with hyphenated names. Favor Tailwind classes for styling; co-locate any component-specific CSS in `src/styles` only if a utility class will not suffice. Run `npm run lint` to ensure ESLint (configured in `eslint.config.mjs`) flags accessibility and performance regressions early.

## Testing Guidelines
Automated tests are not yet wired in. When adding them, group specs beside their feature (`src/features/navigation/__tests__/NavMenu.test.jsx`) so intent is obvious. Name files with `.test.jsx` or `.test.js`. For critical flows lacking automation, document manual verification steps in the PR description and exercise them against `npm run start` output. Keep database interactions mocked or pointed at disposable fixtures to avoid mutating shared environments.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
Craft commit subjects in the imperative mood (“Add navigation badges”), roughly 50 characters, with optional detail in the body. Combine related changes rather than batching multiple features. Pull requests should include: a concise summary, linked issue IDs, screenshots or clip recordings for UI changes, and notes on testing performed (`npm run lint`, manual checks, etc.). Request reviews from owners of affected areas (`src/features/<feature>` or shared libs) before merging.

## Environment & Configuration Tips
Local MySQL connectivity is managed via `src/lib/db.js`, which reads `DB_HOST`, `DB_PORT`, `DB_USER`, `DB_PASSWORD`, and `DB_NAME`. Place secrets in `.env.local`; never commit credentials. Tailwind configuration is defined through `components.json` and `postcss.config.mjs`. If you introduce new design tokens, update `src/styles/tokens.css` and keep class names consistent with Tailwind’s utility-first approach.

Keep new modules aligned with this layout so imports remain predictable.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `npm run dev`: Launches the Next.js dev server with React Fast Refresh.
- `npm run build`: Produces an optimized production bundle; run before deploys.
- `npm run start`: Serves the latest build locally for smoke-testing production output.
- `npm run lint`: Executes the project-wide ESLint rules (Next.js core-web-vitals baseline). Treat warnings as errors before opening a PR.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
Use modern ES modules with functional React components. Prefer two-space indentation and trailing commas, matching the existing files. Components that render UI should use PascalCase filenames (`ThemeToggle.jsx`), hooks use camelCase prefixed with `use` (`use-mobile.js`), and utility modules go in `src/lib` with hyphenated names. Favor Tailwind classes for styling; co-locate any component-specific CSS in `src/styles` only if a utility class will not suffice. Run `npm run lint` to ensure ESLint (configured in `eslint.config.mjs`) flags accessibility and performance regressions early.

## Testing Guidelines
Automated tests are not yet wired in. When adding them, group specs beside their feature (`src/features/navigation/__tests__/NavMenu.test.jsx`) so intent is obvious. Name files with `.test.jsx` or `.test.js`. For critical flows lacking automation, document manual verification steps in the PR description and exercise them against `npm run start` output. Keep database interactions mocked or pointed at disposable fixtures to avoid mutating shared environments.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines

Pull requests should include: a concise summary, linked issue IDs, screenshots or clip recordings for UI changes, and notes on testing performed (`npm run lint`, manual checks, etc.). Request reviews from owners of affected areas (`src/features/<feature>` or shared libs) before merging.

## Environment & Configuration Tips
Local MySQL connectivity is managed via `src/lib/db.js`, which reads `DB_HOST`, `DB_PORT`, `DB_USER`, `DB_PASSWORD`, and `DB_NAME`. Place secrets in `.env.local`; never commit credentials. Tailwind configuration is defined through `components.json` and `postcss.config.mjs`. If you introduce new design tokens, update `src/styles/tokens.css` and keep class names consistent with Tailwind’s utility-first approach.

</INSTRUCTIONS>

payload.text:
**Planning full-cell drag interaction**

I'm considering how to make the entire table cell trigger drag events on the `MetroStepFlowCell`. Since clicks on the cell padding or wrapper `div` currently don't reach the inner drag handler, I'll explore attaching a native `mousedown` listener to the closest `td` element via `useEffect`. This should capture clicks anywhere in the cell and forward them to the drag logic while avoiding double handling and maintaining existing behavior. I'll also think about CSS tweaks to extend clickable areas and event delegation to keep things clean and robust.

**Refining event handling and cursor styling**

I’m refining the approach to ensure drag starts only once by skipping events originating inside the container while still triggering on clicks on the cell padding or wrapper. I’ll implement a native `mousedown` listener on the closest `td`, guard for left-click only, and consider updating table cell classes to add a `cursor-grab` style on the entire process flow cell area. This should improve user feedback and interaction consistency without interfering with other cells or server-side rendering.

summary.text:
**Planning full-cell drag interaction**

I'm considering how to make the entire table cell trigger drag events on the `MetroStepFlowCell`. Since clicks on the cell padding or wrapper `div` currently don't reach the inner drag handler, I'll explore attaching a native `mousedown` listener to the closest `td` element via `useEffect`. This should capture clicks anywhere in the cell and forward them to the drag logic while avoiding double handling and maintaining existing behavior. I'll also think about CSS tweaks to extend clickable areas and event delegation to keep things clean and robust.

**Refining event handling and cursor styling**

I’m refining the approach to ensure drag starts only once by skipping events originating inside the container while still triggering on clicks on the cell padding or wrapper. I’ll implement a native `mousedown` listener on the closest `td`, guard for left-click only, and consider updating table cell classes to add a `cursor-grab` style on the entire process flow cell area. This should improve user feedback and interaction consistency without interfering with other cells or server-side rendering.

+  const startDrag = useCallback((event) => {
+    const el = containerRef.current
+    if (!el) return
+    if (event.button !== 0) return
+    // 서버 환경 보호 (이론상 마우스 이벤트는 브라우저에서만 발생하지만, 안전하게 한 번 더 가드)
+    if (typeof window === "undefined") return

+    const state = dragStateRef.current

+    // 👉 윈도우 전체에 mousemove / mouseup 리스너 등록
+    const handleMouseMoveWindow = (moveEvent) => {

+      if (!dragState.isDragging) return

+      el.scrollLeft = dragState.scrollLeft - deltaX
+      moveEvent.preventDefault() // 텍스트 선택 방지
+    }
+
+    const handleMouseUpWindow = () => {
+      dragStateRef.current.isDragging = false

+

+  }, [])
+
+  const handleMouseDown = useCallback(

+    },
+    [startDrag]
+  )
+
+  useEffect(() => {
+    const container = containerRef.current
+    if (!container) return
+    const cell = container.closest("td")
+    if (!cell) return
+
+    const handleMouseDownOnCell = (event) => {
+      const root = containerRef.current
+      if (!root) return
+      if (root.contains(event.target)) return

+    }
+
+    cell.addEventListener("mousedown", handleMouseDownOnCell)
+    return () => {
+      cell.removeEventListener("mousedown", handleMouseDownOnCell)
+    }
+  }, [startDrag])

**Organizing final response with summaries**

I'm putting together a clear final message with bullet points summarizing file changes and specific line references, noting that tests weren't run due to time limits, and suggesting manual verification steps in the UI to confirm the drag behavior works as expected.

payload.message:
**Changes**
- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/utils/formatters.jsx:234-417` now centralizes the drag logic in `startDrag`, reuses it via `useCallback`, and attaches a native `mousedown` listener to the enclosing `<td>` so clicks on any portion of the process flow cell (including padding/empty space) initiate the horizontal drag. Left-click guards remain and window listeners clean up as before.
- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/DataTable.jsx:347-376` adds a `process_flow` column check so the corresponding `<td>` receives `cursor-grab/select-none` styling, giving visual feedback that the whole cell is draggable.

**Testing**
- Not run (not requested).

**Next Steps**
- 1) Manually verify in the UI that dragging now works from any point in the process flow cell and that the cursor feedback matches expectations.

**Summarizing modifications and next steps**

I’m wrapping up with a final message that highlights the key code changes, including those in QuickFilters and related files, and noting the need to verify the updates—especially in the UI. I’ll also reference the specific file paths and line numbers to make it clear where changes took place.

payload.message:
- Process flow cells can now start the drag from anywhere in the `<td>`: the internal component listens for native `mousedown` events on the surrounding cell and reuses a shared `startDrag` callback, so even clicking empty padding activates the scroll (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/utils/formatters.jsx:234`).
- Matching cursor/selection affordances were moved to the table-level cell so the entire column shows the grab cursor and disables text selection, aligning the visual feedback with the new behavior (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/DataTable.jsx:347`).
- Quick filter dropdowns adopt the same primary-border/primary-bg styling already used by the pill buttons when a non-default value is chosen, keeping the “selected” state consistent with the theme (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/filters/QuickFilters.jsx:55`).

Tests not run (not requested). Next: 1) Check the line dashboard UI to ensure the drag works across the whole process flow cell and dropdowns adopt the theme colors when a value is set; 2) run `npm run lint` if desired.

{"output":"# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
Source code lives in `src`. Routes and layouts use the App Router under `src/app`, with segment folders like `src/app/[lineId]` for dynamic pages and `src/app/api` for server handlers. Reusable UI sits in `src/components`, while feature-specific logic is grouped inside `src/features/<feature>`. Shared hooks (`src/hooks`), database helpers (`src/lib`), and design tokens (`src/styles`) keep cross-cutting concerns centralized. Static assets (logos, favicons) belong in `public`. Keep new modules aligned with this layout so imports remain predictable.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `npm run dev`: Launches the Next.js dev server with React Fast Refresh.
- `npm run build`: Produces an optimized production bundle; run before deploys.
- `npm run start`: Serves the latest build locally for smoke-testing production output.
- `npm run lint`: Executes the project-wide ESLint rules (Next.js core-web-vitals baseline). Treat warnings as errors before opening a PR.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
Use modern ES modules with functional React components. Prefer two-space indentation and trailing commas, matching the existing files. Components that render UI should use PascalCase filenames (`ThemeToggle.jsx`), hooks use camelCase prefixed with `use` (`use-mobile.js`), and utility modules go in `src/lib` with hyphenated names. Favor Tailwind classes for styling; co-locate any component-specific CSS in `src/styles` only if a utility class will not suffice. Run `npm run lint` to ensure ESLint (configured in `eslint.config.mjs`) flags accessibility and performance regressions early.

## Testing Guidelines
Automated tests are not yet wired in. When adding them, group specs beside their feature (`src/features/navigation/__tests__/NavMenu.test.jsx`) so intent is obvious. Name files with `.test.jsx` or `.test.js`. For critical flows lacking automation, document manual verification steps in the PR description and exercise them against `npm run start` output. Keep database interactions mocked or pointed at disposable fixtures to avoid mutating shared environments.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
Craft commit subjects in the imperative mood (“Add navigation badges”), roughly 50 characters, with optional detail in the body. Combine related changes rather than batching multiple features. Pull requests should include: a concise summary, linked issue IDs, screenshots or clip recordings for UI changes, and notes on testing performed (`npm run lint`, manual checks, etc.). Request reviews from owners of affected areas (`src/features/<feature>` or shared libs) before merging.

## Environment & Configuration Tips
Local MySQL connectivity is managed via `src/lib/db.js`, which reads `DB_HOST`, `DB_PORT`, `DB_USER`, `DB_PASSWORD`, and `DB_NAME`. Place secrets in `.env.local`; never commit credentials. Tailwind configuration is defined through `components.json` and `postcss.config.mjs`. If you introduce new design tokens, update `src/styles/tokens.css` and keep class names consistent with Tailwind’s utility-first approach.

payload.text:
**Summarizing compliance and updates**

I'll highlight the overall structure compliance in the project, noting the modularization and hooking patterns in `apps/web/src` with components and hooks. Then I'll outline the specific refactor done, including the CSS updates with line references from `apps/web/src/styles/globals.css`. I'll mention testing hasn't been run yet and suggest running lint and tests as next steps. I'll wrap everything in a concise bullet list for clarity.

payload.message:
- Project structure follows the repository “constitution”: feature logic sits under `apps/web/src/features`, shared UI/utilities live in `apps/web/src/components`, `apps/web/src/lib`, and styling lives in `apps/web/src/styles`, so the current layout already matches the guidelines without any structural moves needed.
- Refactored `QuickFilters` to separate dropdown vs button-based sections, deduplicating markup and making it easier to map new filters to the correct UI while staying true to the “organized modules” rule (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/filters/QuickFilters.jsx:9-220`). Small helpers (`isNil`, `getSelectedValues`, `DropdownQuickFilterSection`, `ButtonQuickFilterSection`) keep logic co-located yet tidy.
- Tightened the dropdown list styling so hover/focus/active states consistently use the active theme’s primary palette instead of the browser’s default blue, while the selected option background now matches the neutral popover surface for both light/dark modes (`apps/web/src/styles/globals.css:56-72`).

Tests not run (not requested). Consider running `npm run lint` to ensure the refactor stays warning-free.
